perturbation.original_text: The term of this Agreement shall be for one (1) year commencing on the Effective Date and automatically renewing annually thereafter, unless either party provides a thirty-day notice of written termination one to the other ("Term").
perturbation.changed_text: The term of this Agreement shall be for one (1) year commencing on the Effective Date and automatically renewing annually thereafter, unless either party provides a five-day notice of written termination one to the other ("Term").
perturbation.explanation: The contract originally requires a thirty-day notice for termination. Reducing this to a five-day notice may contradict state laws requiring longer notice periods for contract terminations, depending on the specific jurisdiction and nature of the agreement. Many states require a 'reasonable' amount of time for providing notices, which could be longer than five days depending on the circumstance.
perturbation.contradicted_law: Potentially contradicts state laws regarding reasonable notice periods for contract termination. Principles of good faith and fair dealing may imply longer required notice.

perturbation.original_text: Said written approval must be given within five (5) business days of Talent's receipt or said usage shall be deemed unapproved.
perturbation.changed_text: Said written approval must be given within one (1) business day of Talent's receipt or said usage shall be deemed unapproved.
perturbation.explanation: The original text allows five business days for Talent to provide written approval. Reducing this to one business day places an unreasonable burden on Talent, potentially conflicting with principles of fairness and good faith in contract law. This timeline is too short to allow for adequate review by the Talent, and many states require parties to have a reasonable amount of time to properly review legal documents.
perturbation.contradicted_law: Potentially violates principles of fairness and good faith dealing implied in contract law. May conflict with state laws requiring reasonable time for review and approval of contractual terms.

perturbation.original_text: ESSI shall have the right to terminate this Agreement upon ten (10) days prior written notice to Talent in the event Talent fails to perform the duties set forth in Paragraph 4 hereof or breaches any other covenant or agreement set forth herein and fails to cure same (if curable) within seven (7) days of receipt of written notice.
perturbation.changed_text: ESSI shall have the right to terminate this Agreement immediately without any prior written notice to Talent in the event Talent fails to perform the duties set forth in Paragraph 4 hereof or breaches any other covenant or agreement set forth herein and fails to cure same (if curable) within two (2) days of receipt of written notice.
perturbation.explanation: The original text requires ten days' notice before ESSI can terminate the agreement, giving Talent seven days to cure any breach. Removing the notice requirement and reducing the cure period to two days contradicts principles of fairness and due process. Many jurisdictions mandate a reasonable opportunity to cure a breach, and immediate termination with only two days to cure is unlikely to be considered reasonable, particularly given the complexity of potential breaches.
perturbation.contradicted_law: Conflicts with implied covenants of good faith and fair dealing in contract law. May violate state laws requiring reasonable notice and opportunity to cure contractual breaches.
